doc.title: Supportive terms of trade continue to underpin Peru and Chile external trade Exporters continued to grow in Peru and Chile... but have proved stagnant in Colombia Colombia's sequential trade deficit i

passages.text: Supportive terms of trade continue to underpin Peru and Chile external trade Exporters continued to grow in Peru and Chile... but have proved stagnant in Colombia Colombia's sequential trade deficit is quickly widening

Given their commodity- based export sectors, the Andean economies are highly dependent on the evolution of export prices and thus terms of trade. Despite the heightened risks to U.S. and global activity stemming from trade and geopolitical risks, both Peru and Chile have enjoyed very supportive terms of trade levels when compared to last- 20- year averages.

In Peru in particular, terms of trade rose \(16.2\%\) oya in the second quarter of 2025, mainly due to higher export prices \((11.1\%)\) oya), led by traditional mining products and to a lesser extent by non- traditional products such as fishery. Reinforcing this dynamic was a \(4.3\%\) oya decline in import prices, mainly associated with lower oil prices and cheaper industrial inputs, consistent with lower producer prices in China. Chile's terms of trade also gained in 2Q, in July sitting \(26\%\) above the 2005- 23 average. The case is different for Colombia, as terms of trade deteriorated strongly in the second quarter (Figure 1).
Figure 1: Terms of Trade % deviation from 2005-23 avg

With the export price tailwind, it is not surprising to see Peru's exports showing a strong performance. As Figure 2 shows, when seasonally adjusted (J.P. Morgan's correction), exports (in value) have soared, up by \(16\% y / y\) in the first half of the year supported by record- high export prices. That said, in the last 3 months Chile's exports also gained YTD, up by \(4.8\% y / y\) , sa. Meanwhile in Colombia, exports marginally gained by \(1.5\% y / y\) . Despite the annual gains, the data show deceleration, with negative sequential variations in Peru and Colombia.
Figure 2: Merchandise exports US\$bn, 3mma, sa by J.P.Morgan

Meanwhile, gains in economic activity have pushed imports higher, despite lower prices in some cases. Chile's imports increased by \(10.7\% y / y\) through July, while Colombia's rose by \(9.4\%\) in the first half of the year. Peru's imports growth has been more dynamic, at \(12.8\% y / y\) (Figure 3). In all three countries domestic demand growth has been firm (see note and note), and imports have outpaced exports in the second quarter of the year. The sequential gains observed in both Chile and Colombia are worth mentioning, particularly the latter as it seems explained by unsustainable fiscal expansion. Sequentially, imports leaped by \(25.2\% 3\mathrm{m} / 3\mathrm{m}\) saar in 2Q in Colombia, and \(19.9\%\) in Chile.
Figure 3: Merchandise imports (CIF) US\$bn, sa by J.P. Morgan

In terms of the trade balance, Peru and Chile continue to post hefty merchandise trade surpluses, albeit narrowing. Conversely, Colombia's trade deficit has widened since the start of the year, and has regained levels not seen since early 2022. Seasonally adjusted, the last three- month annualized balance logged US\$24.8bn in Peru (equivalent to \(8.3\%\) of GDP) and US\$7.9bn in Chile ( \(2.3\%\) of GDP). In contrast, Colombia's deficit soared to US\$22.2bn in 2Q215, or about \(5.2\%\) of GDP (Figure 4).

Colombia's widening trade deficit has been partially offset by remittance inflows, which have helped keep the current account deficit below historical averages in recent years (see note). But remittances seem poised to stabilize at best (see note), and the sequential trade deficit to continue widening as domestic demand is fueled by an expansive fiscal policy (see note).
Figure 4: Merchandise trade balance US\\(bn, last 3m, sa, annualized
Source: Central Banks and J.P. Morgan
Week of September 1 - 5
Sources: DANE, BanRep and J.P. Morgan
Week of September 1 - 5
Mon Economic activity Sep 1
